story:
The Good News: we’re opening a wine & cheese loft in downtown St. Pete! It’s going to be awesome. We love it, and we can’t wait to share it with you. Now we need your help to bring the good community vibes & support that made us fall in love with St. Pete many years ago. Wanna know more? Read our story, choose your Perk, and help us spread the word!

A LITTLE BIT ABOUT US

MUST Wine Loft began as a passion project of Jessica Arkwright - a Sommelier - and Raymond Cotteret - a Chef. We met in 2014 at Locale Market - Jessica was the Beverage Director and Raymond was the Cheesemonger.

As explained by Raymond, "She's the wine and I'm the cheese." A natural pairing of friendship was instantly born from our shared love for wine & cheese.

And then we met Alex - our "fresh bread" - he brings good energy and shares our love of good food & wine (and the height that Raymond & Jessica lack). Jodi - who introduced us - also joined our team and brings the dollars and cents as our CPA.

Together, we have been working the past six months to design MUST Wine Loft with a local architect, builder, interior designer and mural artist Carrie Jadus. Now, we're ready to present our hopes and dreams for MUST Wine Loft, and invite YOU to join us in getting our doors open in November (we'll be open in October for private events).

So why are we doing an Indiegogo Campaign? Two reasons.

The first – we want our community to be involved in our opening!!! We believe in the saying, "it takes a village to raise" - well, in our case, a wine bar - and want to offer YOU a way to get to know us before we open, and we want to get to know you so that we can create your new favorite place to be when you’re not at home.

The second - Construction costs are more than we expected, and getting our doors open has taken longer than we hoped. We don’t want to cut corners to save on costs because we want MUST Wine Loft to transport you when you step through our doors. We want to create amazing dining experiences for you. We want you to have fun when you’re visiting us, as if you’re visiting a dear friend who always has interesting wines and cheeses. We want to carry wines and cheeses that you’ve never heard of and make discovery a fun tasting adventure, as well as stock your favorite wine and go-to dinner that you crave at the end of a long day. We want to cater your special celebrations and help you celebrate the everyday as much as your special moments. We want YOU to become part of our story by contributing to our opening and we want to invite you to be there when we open our doors our first day!

We are asking for campaign contributions to help pay for the beautiful custom painting by Carrie Jadus that we’re installing on our wall above our "wine & cheese bar" which we're inviting YOU to be a part of by having your name painted on a Barrel - this will be hand-painted on canvas by local artist Carrie Jadus, then custom-framed. In other words, we'll take this with us even if we outgrow our current space, and you will forever be remembered as our MUST O.G. Supporter as you come along with us!

We are also raising money for the wines we’re hand-selecting special for you, the t-shirts we look forward to seeing you in around town, and the cheeses we look forward to introducing you to soon. Every little bit helps a lot, and even if you can’t afford to contribute, you can help by sharing our campaign.

Photos of Must Wine Loft as we undergo renovations to bring our former-laundromat up to code:

We have put together contribution packages in the hopes of meeting you in person, because we love to say "Thank you" over wine and cheese. However, we also understand that not every contributor lives in St. Petersburg, FL and we have come up with some long-distance perks in appreciation of your long-distance support.

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

We are here to raise $30,000. Every contribution directly helps us pay for our remaining build-out, gets our shelves stocked, and gets our doors open.

So what’s in it for you? Well, because every person loves differently, we usually give differently too, and so we’ve tried to put together a few different ways to contribute to our campaign and share your love.

We want to make sure that we offer some amazing perks for those of you who help make our opening happen. Of course this includes swag, but we also want to offer curated, highly-customized experiences for those who have a special date or occasion in mind – Pick the “Night in Paris” Perk if you would like a fully-curated french-themed dining experience for you and a date at MUST Wine Loft.

Did you know that we love to teach pairing classes? It's our favorite way to get to know you! Raymond loves to share his 40+ years of cooking experience and Jessica loves to geek out over wine & vermouth. Sign up for our “Passport Series” Perk to take six classes for the price of four. Want to dive even deeper into a wine region or learn how to make Coq au Vin or unique vermouth cocktails? Then pick our “Master Class" Perk and we’ll customize a private two-hour master class for you and three friends on the topic of your choosing.

Become part of our “Bottle & Barrel Club” and have your name (or your business name) hand-painted onto a Barrel or Bottle by Carrie Jadus – this extra-special, beautiful painting will hang permanently above our wine & cheese bar, so you’ll see your name every time you visit us AND receive a 15% discount on your wine purchases every visit for a full year. We also invite you to join our "Cork & Curd Club"  members and enjoy a complimentary tasting every month on "Third Curdsday" as we roll out the red carpet and show off our new wine & cheese features from appellations around the world.

Not sure what perks you want, yet still want to contribute? Awesome! We’ve got a “Secret Perk” option for those who want to contribute anonymously and/or request a perk we haven’t thought of – we want to hear from you and we want to get to know you so that we can serve you better!

YOUR IMPACT

Why this and why now? When we first scouted our location for MUST Wine Loft, we knew we wanted to be near downtown but not directly in the hustle of downtown. We looked at multiple locations, but this one grabbed us immediately. Raymond lives in Old Northeast and Jessica lives in Crescent Heights (after spending four years living in the Old Northeast), so the Old Northeast neighborhood is near and dear to our hearts. We hope to add to the charm we adore by offering an intimate place for our neighbors to relax and enjoy a drink and bite off the beaten path of touristy Beach Drive and the bar bustle of Central Ave. We’ve met many of our neighbors already, who have shared their excitement to have a wine & cheese shop opening nearby, and we look forward to meeting many more of our neighbors and new friends like you at MUST Wine Loft!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

We know that not everyone has the ability to contribute, and that’s ok! What we do ask is that you share your excitement, our story, our video, and our campaign. Help us spread the word, which will only help spread the MUST love too! Also, if you’re not already, please follow us on Instagram @MUSTWineLoftDTSP for all sorts of updates and sneak peeks!

We met in 2014 at Locale Market - Jessica was the Beverage Director and Raymond was the Cheesemonger.As explained by Raymond, "She's the wine and I'm the cheese." A natural pairing of friendship was instantly born from our shared love for wine & cheese.And then we met Alex - our "fresh bread" - he brings good energy and shares our love of good food & wine (and the height that Raymond & Jessica lack). Jodi - who introduced us - also joined our team and brings the dollars and cents as our CPA.Together, we have been working the past six months to design MUST Wine Loft with a local architect, builder, interior designer and mural artist Carrie Jadus. Now, we're ready to present our hopes and dreams for MUST Wine Loft, and invite YOU to join us in getting our doors open in November (we'll be open in October for private events).So why are we doing an Indiegogo Campaign? Two reasons.The first – we want our community to be involved in our opening!!! We believe in the saying, "it takes a village to raise" - well, in our case, a wine bar - and want to offer YOU a way to get to know us before we open, and we want to get to know you so that we can create your new favorite place to be when you’re not at home.The second - Construction costs are more than we expected, and getting our doors open has taken longer than we hoped. We don’t want to cut corners to save on costs because we want MUST Wine Loft to transport you when you step through our doors. We want to create amazing dining experiences for you. We want you to have fun when you’re visiting us, as if you’re visiting a dear friend who always has interesting wines and cheeses. We want to carry wines and cheeses that you’ve never heard of and make discovery a fun tasting adventure, as well as stock your favorite wine and go-to dinner that you crave at the end of a long day. We want to cater your special celebrations and help you celebrate the everyday as much as your special moments. We want YOU to become part of our story by contributing to our opening and we want to invite you to be there when we open our doors our first day!We are asking for campaign contributions to help pay for the beautiful custom painting by Carrie Jadus that we’re installing on our wall above our "wine & cheese bar" which we're inviting YOU to be a part of by having your name painted on a Barrel - this will be hand-painted on canvas by local artist Carrie Jadus, then custom-framed. In other words, we'll take this with us even if we outgrow our current space, and you will forever be remembered as our MUST O.G. Supporter as you come along with us!We are also raising money for the wines we’re hand-selecting special for you, the t-shirts we look forward to seeing you in around town, and the cheeses we look forward to introducing you to soon. Every little bit helps a lot, and even if you can’t afford to contribute, you can help by sharing our campaign.Photos of Must Wine Loft as we undergo renovations to bring our former-laundromat up to code:We have put together contribution packages in the hopes of meeting you in person, because we love to say "Thank you" over wine and cheese. However, we also understand that not every contributor lives in St. Petersburg, FL and we have come up with some long-distance perks in appreciation of your long-distance support.WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GETWe are here to raise $30,000. Every contribution directly helps us pay for our remaining build-out, gets our shelves stocked, and gets our doors open.So what’s in it for you? Well, because every person loves differently, we usually give differently too, and so we’ve tried to put together a few different ways to contribute to our campaign and share your love.We want to make sure that we offer some amazing perks for those of you who help make our opening happen. Of course this includes swag, but we also want to offer curated, highly-customized experiences for those who have a special date or occasion in mind – Pick the “Night in Paris” Perk if you would like a fully-curated french-themed dining experience for you and a date at MUST Wine Loft.Did you know that we love to teach pairing classes? It's our favorite way to get to know you! Raymond loves to share his 40+ years of cooking experience and Jessica loves to geek out over wine & vermouth. Sign up for our “Passport Series” Perk to take six classes for the price of four. Want to dive even deeper into a wine region or learn how to make Coq au Vin or unique vermouth cocktails? Then pick our “Master Class" Perk and we’ll customize a private two-hour master class for you and three friends on the topic of your choosing.Become part of our “Bottle & Barrel Club” and have your name (or your business name) hand-painted onto a Barrel or Bottle by Carrie Jadus – this extra-special, beautiful painting will hang permanently above our wine & cheese bar, so you’ll see your name every time you visit us AND receive a 15% discount on your wine purchases every visit for a full year. We also invite you to join our "Cork & Curd Club"  members and enjoy a complimentary tasting every month on "Third Curdsday" as we roll out the red carpet and show off our new wine & cheese features from appellations around the world.Not sure what perks you want, yet still want to contribute? Awesome! We’ve got a “Secret Perk” option for those who want to contribute anonymously and/or request a perk we haven’t thought of – we want to hear from you and we want to get to know you so that we can serve you better!YOUR IMPACTWhy this and why now? When we first scouted our location for MUST Wine Loft, we knew we wanted to be near downtown but not directly in the hustle of downtown. We looked at multiple locations, but this one grabbed us immediately. Raymond lives in Old Northeast and Jessica lives in Crescent Heights (after spending four years living in the Old Northeast), so the Old Northeast neighborhood is near and dear to our hearts. We hope to add to the charm we adore by offering an intimate place for our neighbors to relax and enjoy a drink and bite off the beaten path of touristy Beach Drive and the bar bustle of Central Ave. We’ve met many of our neighbors already, who have shared their excitement to have a wine & cheese shop opening nearby, and we look forward to meeting many more of our neighbors and new friends like you at MUST Wine Loft!OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELPWe know that not everyone has the ability to contribute, and that’s ok! What we do ask is that you share your excitement, our story, our video, and our campaign. Help us spread the word, which will only help spread the MUST love too! Also, if you’re not already, please follow us on Instagram @MUSTWineLoftDTSP for all sorts of updates and sneak peeks!

story:
The Refillery L.A. is the first mobile refill store in the U.S. built in a van. We currently service West Los Angeles neighborhoods by offering bulk refills of eco-friendly household items to reduce single-use plastic pollution.

To expand our service area and bring refilling to even more neighborhoods in Los Angeles, we need to acquire and build out a second refill van.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $10,000 to help pay for a used van and the build out to get it ready to refill.

Vote with your dollars; every donation is a contribution towards a plastic-free community.

Don't forget to leave us a note and let us know which neighborhood you want to see us in next!

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us spread the word! Tell your friends and family about The Refillery L.A. 

Share and tag us on social media @refilleryla

Visit our current refill van https://www.refilleryla.com/location?view=calen...

story:
About Us

Hi Everyone,

My name is Chelsea and I am an occupational therapist born and raised in Cumberland, Rhode Island. I have been an occupational therapist for eight years now with a variety of experience. Last year, I started a private practice in which we delivered mobile therapy services to the most vulnerable populations in our community, starting in geriatrics and then moving to pediatrics. It has been an absolute privilege utilizing my skill set to serve my local community and provide care during such a difficult time.

In addition to being an OT, I am also a mom of two amazing children. My son was born with complex medical and developmental needs. He has required therapy, nursing, medication and various forms of support since he was 10 days old. It has been through this experience that I have learned more about disabilities than anyone could have ever taught me in an educational setting. It was through his challenges and victories that I had the courage to build programs that directly targeted children just like him. During the pandemic, my son regressed significantly. I looked around for help since he was not able to access any of his therapeutic services. I realized that there were currently no options in our community for this style of care. It was at that time that I knew we had to create a pediatric program. 

After successfully building a mobile practice that specialized in complex kiddos, we began to realize that both typical and atypical children have been significantly impacted by the lack of socialization, increased amount of screen time, and in ability to engage with professionals directly. From these observations as well as thorough market analysis, we have decided to create a new pediatric social and play-based clinic to help pull these children out of the pandemic through the effective delivery of skilled occupational, physical and speech therapy services.

Our mission is simple:

Help typical and atypical children through developmentally appropriate, social and play-based therapeutic services that are accessible, safe and convenient. 

Pediatric therapeutic clinics require a significant amount of specialized equipment, assessments, technology and expertise. When building our first practice, we were able to start slow, taking only as many patients as we could staff. Our overhead and cashflow grew slowly so that we could maintain the quality of care while offsetting the operational costs. In a brick and mortar style practice, we have to pay for these expenses up front.

In order to provide the level of care stated in our mission, our clinic will require rock walls, specially designed swing rings, crash pads, sensory equipment, zip lines, balls, monkey bars, slides, cargo nets, climbing structures and more. The office will require state of the art technology that will allow parents to view treatment sessions from a device, security systems to maintain the highest levels of safety, and sensory equipment for treatment of complex processing disorders. Our team has joined forces with other clinicians around the country to participate in research studies on various evidence-based programs, bringing the best services possible to our community. Donating to this cause would directly impact the children in our town as well as other neighboring areas.  

Funding Needs:

Currently our clinic is being specifically built to meet the unique needs of our children. Lighting, design, privacy and safety have all been taken into consideration in the design. We have been slowly attempting to purchase equipment from our list of necessary items. These include:

  • Swing rig and swings: vestibular and proprioceptive input are a necessary component to sensory integration therapy, utilized to help treat disorders such as autism, ADHD, developmental coordination disorders, hydrocephalus and more. The swing rig is being custom built to meet the needs of the clinic and will cost $5000. The swings, safety snaps, ropes and height adjustment hooks will cost an additional $3000. This is one of our largest expenses however it is imperative to the effective treatment of so many pediatric conditions.
  • Rock wall and monkey bars: children with developmental and physical abilities require strengthening of core, grip and gross motor skills however they need an engaging and confidence building environment. The rock wall is a 15 foot wide x 8 foot tall structure with various holds and obstacles. With assistance, children climb and move transversely through the structure, not only building strength and confidence but decreasing doubt and fear. The heavy input through the joints provides calming sensations to children with otherwise struggle with sensory organization. The rock wall with all hardware, fixtures and safety mats will cost $5000. Monkey bars address a variety of needs including gravitational instability, shoulder and grip strength, and proprioceptive input. This equipment allows children to practice activities seen on a typical playground, in a safe and positive environment. The cost of this structure and safety mats below will cost $2400.
  • Assessment tools: in order to provide the highest quality of evidence-based services, our clinicians will utilize standardized assessment tools as well as clinical observations in order to create the most appropriate treatment plans. Assessment tools for occupational, physical and speech therapy services range anywhere from $500 to $1000 each. Each speciality will require multiple tools to address the age range of our target market as well as a variety of developmental needs. 

These items represent just a small fraction of the expenses. Our startup budget is approximately $40,000. We have been able to save and boot strap approximately $20,000 thus far. We are systematically purchasing and ordering the most necessary equipment in a prioritized manner however in order to provide superb services the day the doors open, we must find a way to raise the remainder of the funds. 

The Impact

So far, we have been able to reach out into the community and treat the most medically complex and fragile populations of our community. However, children require safe social and play-based experiences for proper development. The pandemic has deprived our community of these opportunities. In addition to providing direct therapy services, our clinic will be providing group based services that will be cheaper than the cost of a co-pay. This will allow more children to be under the watchful eye of a clinical specialist, increasing accessibility. Our groups will include social skills, adapted bootcamps, fine motor, feeding teams, Mommy and Me classes, children's yoga, bike riding and more!

Risks & Challenges

Starting a practice right before the beginning of the pandemic sure made for a wild ride. I found myself having to pivot my entire business model on a dime in order to survive. Although I have confidence in my clinical skills, it is my ability to find opportunity in any situation that has helped our practice survive throughout this first year. The risks and challenges remain plentiful: COVID restrictions, fearful parents, rising costs due to economic uncertainty to name a few. However it is my ultimate belief that this clinic will serve children like my son, who require specialized services to thrive at their fullest potential. The most important key to success of any project is the team and culture behind it. I have been incredibly blessed with the steady loyalty of an amazing group of women who believes in my vision whole-heartedly. Without their dedication, commitment and compassion, our practice would cease to exist. Although there are many challenges, I have incredible faith in our mission, vision and team. 

Other Ways You Can Help

 Here at Bizzy Bees, we appreciate you taking the time to read about our vision. We know that many are unable to contribute during such difficult times. If possible, spread the news! Share and follow us on social media, spread word around town and follow our progress! We are looking forward to servicing our community and again we are extremely thankful for everyones support along the way.

Bizzy Bees Therapy Coming Soon... May 2021 :)

story:
Summary

Historic Restoration, Learning/Teaching Homestead, Artist Sanctuary 

 

We are going to create a learning/teaching homestead with an artist santuary. In addition to hosting artists, we plan on offering design classes with a focus on sustainability and opening our homestead to the community at large. 

Now more than ever, having control of your food, and creating nourishment for your family is vital for health and survival. 

The food we eat passes through many hands before it hits our tables. 

We will teach you skills to grow your own food in small space, put it by, and keep you and your family healthy and strong. 

The Impact

Teaching Self Sufficiency and Mindfulness and Supporting Emerging Artists

We love old places and this one deserves a second chance in life. She may have been neglected, but she has good bones and a great foundation. 

I am originally from West Virginia from an old, mountain family that settled in the region before there was the United States. My ancestors foraged and lived off the land and have a long history of self-sufficient and sustainable living. It’s in my DNA. 

We want to teach people the best practices for growing the most amount of healthy, organic food in the least amount of space and tried and true methods of putting things by. Also, we will teach classes in sustainable floral design, soap making, and other practical skills. Working with nature creates a state of flow and mindfulness and we want to share that gift. 

Classes will be made available for day-trippers or people staying in the area. They will be small groups, taught by local experts. 

Resident artists will be encouraged to show and speak about their work at a local arts center and will be matched with working professionals who will perform 2-3 studio visits during their stay. We want this to be a place to support emerging and mid-career artists and to encourage those who are looking to build a career in creative pursuits. 

In lieu of payment, artists will donate a piece of their work created during their stay and will be encouraged to show their work and talk about their process to the local community.  It's an excellent opportunity for emerging and mid career artists learn from working professionals and gain more exposure and talk about their work. 

 

 

This is a lifelong dream of ours and Enrique, Lavender, William I and are very excited about restoring a neglected home, giving back to our community and offering artists a place to sprout their journeys.

What We Need & What You Get 

We need $20K in Funding you get a Great Experience

We are seeking $20K. We will use the funds to help supplement the initial down payment and closing costs, establish a 503(c) foundation to offset the maintenance and administrative fees and to develop a book documenting the process. The entire project will be underwritten by Rose Red & Lavender, and the Sevilla Family. 

You get to be a part of this amazing project and you are investing in this. In exchange for your kindness we are offering the following: 

 

  • $5+ Our eternal gratitude
  • $25 Handmade soap, made with pure ingredients and love by, Kimberly Sevilla
  • $50 credit in the book as a friend of the project
  • $100 book documenting the restoration of the Blue House with credit in the book
  • $250 floral design class with Kimberly Sevilla at Blue House Hudson Valley
  • $500 weekend stay for 2 in the artist's apartment 
  • $1000 weekend stay for 2 in the artist's apartment plus a private workshop for 2
  • $2500 weekend stay for two plus one private workshop and a painting created by an artist in residence
  • $5000 Private floral design class for 5 at a location of your choice in the NYC metropolitan area and a home or garden evaluation of plant recommendations and advice. 

 

 

The Location

Nestled in the Hudson Valley, close enough to New York City, Sanctuary and Spirit of a Salon

Located about an hour and a half north of New York City and walkable to a historic village, this location offers opportunities to be in the country but still accessible to the city. Minutes from the property are miles of hiking trails, preserved open spaces and forests. 

Nearby are Dia Beacon, Storm King Art Center, Magazzino Italian Art Center, Thomas Cole Hudson River Museum, Historic Hyde Park, The Glynwood Center for Regional Food and Farming, and the Culinary Institute of America.

The

Hudson Valley is known for its stunning mountainscape beauty, preserved open spaces, organic farms, and a plethora of festivals and arts foundations. 

We intend to transform this historic farmhouse into a sanctuary and invite artists to a private space where they can create, unwind, and be inspired. 

While being respectful to its heritage; the finished site will have passive design elements, a fully functioning woodworking studio, a wet studio for pottery, floral design, and soap making along with organic vegetable gardens and perhaps a goat or two and some chickens. The artist’s residence will have an en-suite, private studio, separate bedroom, and a private bath and kitchen. 

We intend on opening our home and hearth for select guests to relax and unwind and have meaningful conversations and discussions in the spirit of a modern-day salon.

 

 

Why 

Hi, my name is Kimberly Sevilla and I am the owner of Rose Red & Lavender. I founded my business in Williamsburg Brooklyn in 2008 out of a desire to share my love of plants and flowers with my community and to empower people to embrace the natural world by teaching classes in organic gardening and sustainable design. Sadly, the beautiful, old complex that housed my business was torn down in 2018 to build condos.

My Family and I are launching a new project. We want to save this C1870's Hudson Valley farmhouse from the bulldozer and will need your help. 

Here is a little video of me and our little shop made in 2012. I thought I looked old and fat, but that's a different story. 

 

 

 
 

Risks & Challenges

Someone else will buy it and tear it down, restoring a historic home ain't easy. 

This house recently went on the market. We are concerned if we don’t act quickly, that someone else will buy it and tear it down to build a McMansion. This would not only impact the local community where the house is located but would also be a tragedy to have such a beautiful treasure put in a landfill. 

We are aware of the difficulties of house restoration and intend on using reclaimed materials when possible and following passive design principles while maintaining the historic context and integrity of the property. We also intend on using professional designers, architects and  contractors for the renovations necessary to make it habitable for the artists and our family. 

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share your expertise and skills, holler from the mountain tops about us.

We understand that not everyone can monetarily support us. That’s OK. We are actively seeking artists and curators who would like to contribute their knowledge and expertise as well as artisans who would like to share their skills with a broader community. 

As you know, people like to support people that they like, if you aren’t the “Artsy” type (as my WV mom would say), sharing our campaign, hollering about us and making some noise about us to your friends and family would go a long way. 

 

About Us

West Virginia Meets Peru (Queens) on the Dance Floor and Creates a  Family and a Floral and Plant Empire 

Kimberly Sevilla is the founder of Rose Red & Lavender, a well-known floral design company located in the New York metro area. Originally from West Virginia, she is an avid gardener and enthusiast of lost arts. Her passion is to empower people to embrace the natural world and be self-sufficient. She teaches classes in sustainable floral design, organic gardening as well as soap-making and ways to use botanical ingredients for scent blending and personal care products. Over the years, she has encouraged dozens of artists to pursue their dreams and has continually provided opportunities for on the job training and mentoring. She sits on the board of Haldane Arts Alliance, a community group dedicated to the support of the arts in public schools and is active in the local Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts organizations as well as environmental programs including River Keepers. 

Enrique Sevilla is an Art Director with over 20 years of experience in working with print and digital design. He is a native New Yorker, originally from Peru and has spent his life surrounded by art. When not creating graphic design work he can be found trolling through museums, sketching and hiking. He loves teaching about the practical and business aspects of working in freelance design. 

Enrique and Kimberly met while tango dancing and are keen fans of contemporary art. They have a large network of friends and associates who make a living through art and design and align themselves with people who are eager to encourage, educate and mentor others. 

Enrique and Kimberly have been married since 2007 and are proud parents of two children William and Lavender. As a family, they have a dog, a cat, and a lizard and two fish. They are excited about the opportunity to save a historic farmhouse and give back to the community.

Their children are excited about saving a historic homestead and having a place to raise chickens, bees, and goats as well as sharing their home and learning from artists and helping them continue their creative journeys.

In their spare time, they enjoy camping, hiking and kayaking, and the occasional karaoke dance party.

Our Senseis

Our inspiration comes from angels in heaven. Blue House Hudson Valley will be dedicated in memory of the following people.

Lois Mallow Galvin - August 1st, 1943 - November 16th, 2019 My aunt, who taught me the old ways of self sufficiency and how to be kind.

Shoukat Khalfan - December 12th, 1950  - November 11th, 2019 My friend, who taught me how to see people's potential and champion them.

Susan Kasen Summer - May 19th, 1942 - February 11th, 2019 My mentor, who taught me to embrace artists and removed the word can’t from my vocabulary.

Working with nature creates a state of flow and mindfulness and we want to share that gift. Classes will be made available for day-trippers or people staying in the area. They will be small groups, taught by local experts. Resident artists will be encouraged to show and speak about their work at a local arts center and will be matched with working professionals who will perform 2-3 studio visits during their stay. We want this to be a place to support emerging and mid-career artists and to encourage those who are looking to build a career in creative pursuits. In lieu of payment, artists will donate a piece of their work created during their stay and will be encouraged to show their work and talk about their process to the local community.  It's an excellent opportunity for emerging and mid career artists learn from working professionals and gain more exposure and talk about their work.   This is a lifelong dream of ours and Enrique, Lavender, William I and are very excited about restoring a neglected home, giving back to our community and offering artists a place to sprout their journeys.What We Need & What You Get We need $20K in Funding you get a Great ExperienceWe are seeking $20K. We will use the funds to help supplement the initial down payment and closing costs, establish a 503(c) foundation to offset the maintenance and administrative fees and to develop a book documenting the process. The entire project will be underwritten by Rose Red & Lavender, and the Sevilla Family. You get to be a part of this amazing project and you are investing in this. In exchange for your kindness we are offering the following:  
$5+ Our eternal gratitude
$25 Handmade soap, made with pure ingredients and love by, Kimberly Sevilla
$50 credit in the book as a friend of the project
$100 book documenting the restoration of the Blue House with credit in the book
$250 floral design class with Kimberly Sevilla at Blue House Hudson Valley
$500 weekend stay for 2 in the artist's apartment 
$1000 weekend stay for 2 in the artist's apartment plus a private workshop for 2
$2500 weekend stay for two plus one private workshop and a painting created by an artist in residence
$5000 Private floral design class for 5 at a location of your choice in the NYC metropolitan area and a home or garden evaluation of plant recommendations and advice. 
  The LocationNestled in the Hudson Valley, close enough to New York City, Sanctuary and Spirit of a SalonLocated about an hour and a half north of New York City and walkable to a historic village, this location offers opportunities to be in the country but still accessible to the city. Minutes from the property are miles of hiking trails, preserved open spaces and forests. Nearby are Dia Beacon, Storm King Art Center, Magazzino Italian Art Center, Thomas Cole Hudson River Museum, Historic Hyde Park, The Glynwood Center for Regional Food and Farming, and the Culinary Institute of America.TheHudson Valley is known for its stunning mountainscape beauty, preserved open spaces, organic farms, and a plethora of festivals and arts foundations. We intend to transform this historic farmhouse into a sanctuary and invite artists to a private space where they can create, unwind, and be inspired. While being respectful to its heritage; the finished site will have passive design elements, a fully functioning woodworking studio, a wet studio for pottery, floral design, and soap making along with organic vegetable gardens and perhaps a goat or two and some chickens. The artist’s residence will have an en-suite, private studio, separate bedroom, and a private bath and kitchen. We intend on opening our home and hearth for select guests to relax and unwind and have meaningful conversations and discussions in the spirit of a modern-day salon.  Why Hi, my name is Kimberly Sevilla and I am the owner of Rose Red & Lavender. I founded my business in Williamsburg Brooklyn in 2008 out of a desire to share my love of plants and flowers with my community and to empower people to embrace the natural world by teaching classes in organic gardening and sustainable design. Sadly, the beautiful, old complex that housed my business was torn down in 2018 to build condos.My Family and I are launching a new project. We want to save this C1870's Hudson Valley farmhouse from the bulldozer and will need your help. Here is a little video of me and our little shop made in 2012. I thought I looked old and fat, but that's a different story.  

 
  Risks & ChallengesSomeone else will buy it and tear it down, restoring a historic home ain't easy. This house recently went on the market. We are concerned if we don’t act quickly, that someone else will buy it and tear it down to build a McMansion. This would not only impact the local community where the house is located but would also be a tragedy to have such a beautiful treasure put in a landfill. We are aware of the difficulties of house restoration and intend on using reclaimed materials when possible and following passive design principles while maintaining the historic context and integrity of the property. We also intend on using professional designers, architects and  contractors for the renovations necessary to make it habitable for the artists and our family.   Other Ways You Can HelpShare your expertise and skills, holler from the mountain tops about us.We understand that not everyone can monetarily support us. That’s OK. We are actively seeking artists and curators who would like to contribute their knowledge and expertise as well as artisans who would like to share their skills with a broader community. As you know, people like to support people that they like, if you aren’t the “Artsy” type (as my WV mom would say), sharing our campaign, hollering about us and making some noise about us to your friends and family would go a long way.  About UsWest Virginia Meets Peru (Queens) on the Dance Floor and Creates a  Family and a Floral and Plant Empire Kimberly Sevilla is the founder of Rose Red & Lavender, a well-known floral design company located in the New York metro area. Originally from West Virginia, she is an avid gardener and enthusiast of lost arts. Her passion is to empower people to embrace the natural world and be self-sufficient. She teaches classes in sustainable floral design, organic gardening as well as soap-making and ways to use botanical ingredients for scent blending and personal care products. Over the years, she has encouraged dozens of artists to pursue their dreams and has continually provided opportunities for on the job training and mentoring. She sits on the board of Haldane Arts Alliance, a community group dedicated to the support of the arts in public schools and is active in the local Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts organizations as well as environmental programs including River Keepers. Enrique Sevilla is an Art Director with over 20 years of experience in working with print and digital design. He is a native New Yorker, originally from Peru and has spent his life surrounded by art. When not creating graphic design work he can be found trolling through museums, sketching and hiking. He loves teaching about the practical and business aspects of working in freelance design. Enrique and Kimberly met while tango dancing and are keen fans of contemporary art. They have a large network of friends and associates who make a living through art and design and align themselves with people who are eager to encourage, educate and mentor others. Enrique and Kimberly have been married since 2007 and are proud parents of two children William and Lavender. As a family, they have a dog, a cat, and a lizard and two fish. They are excited about the opportunity to save a historic farmhouse and give back to the community.Their children are excited about saving a historic homestead and having a place to raise chickens, bees, and goats as well as sharing their home and learning from artists and helping them continue their creative journeys.In their spare time, they enjoy camping, hiking and kayaking, and the occasional karaoke dance party.Our SenseisOur inspiration comes from angels in heaven. Blue House Hudson Valley will be dedicated in memory of the following people.Lois Mallow Galvin - August 1st, 1943 - November 16th, 2019 My aunt, who taught me the old ways of self sufficiency and how to be kind.Shoukat Khalfan - December 12th, 1950  - November 11th, 2019 My friend, who taught me how to see people's potential and champion them.Susan Kasen Summer - May 19th, 1942 - February 11th, 2019 My mentor, who taught me to embrace artists and removed the word can’t from my vocabulary.

story:
Who We Are

The Collective Yoga Co-op is a group of teachers who believe that the yoga world needs to change. No investment groups. No equity firms. No corporate backing. This is yoga for the people, by the people.

In seeking to establish as a nonprofit workers cooperative, we commit to the following:

  • Pop-up yoga classes throughout Chicago, in support of local nonprofits
  • A virtual teaching schedule
  • Centering LGBTQ+ voices and voices of color in our teachers and community
  • A sliding scale drop-in to make yoga accessible

What We Need & What You Get

"A cooperative is not a spectator sport." -Melanie Shellito

We are starting this cooperative because we believe in the power of community. Because we have no interest in the corporate model of yoga, we need capital from you!

We set a goal of $30,000 to achieve the following:

  • Our goal for this Indiegogo campaign is to open a pop-up studio for at least 3-6 months, with the hope of a permanent space as we continue acquiring capital
  • Establish ourselves as an official business in the State of Illinois
  • Legal, registration, trademarking, and filing fees
  • Fair wages for teachers
  • Rent, utilities, insurance for when it's safe to open a brick & mortar studio

Perks you'd get:

  • Most tiers offer 50% off of packages or membership for periods of time
  • After contributing, you'll receive a coupon code to redeem your 50% off on our website. Pricing (before discounts) is as follows:
    • Virtual Drop-In: $20 (suggested)
    • Virtual 5 Pack: $80
    • Virtual 10 Pack: $150
    • Unlimited Month: $99 (inclusive of all virtual and outdoor classes)
    • Outdoor Classes: bring a donation for charity, and please tip your instructor(s) $10-25 sliding scale. If you have the unlimited month, payment to your instructor is included, but please still donate if you can.
  • Depending on the contribution tier and corresponding perk you choose, your per-class spend with us could be as low as $10 per class or less.
  • Every dollar you contribute goes straight to the opening of the studio and your teacher, not an investor's pocket.

What is a cooperative?

A workers cooperative is a democratic solution to business. Rather than a CEO, equity firm, or investment group making decisions on the direction of the business, the worker-owners (teachers) act as a team, and decisions are made by vote. In the spirit of community and democracy, we want our members to have voting power as well. So when it comes down to things like things like scheduling, special workshops, or how we build and grow the studio, you’d get a hand in the decision-making process as a member!

All cooperatives must stand upon 10 principles, and The Collective Yoga Co-op pledges to uphold them at all times to the best of our abilities: self-help, self-responsibility, democracy, equality, equity, solidarity, honesty, openness, social responsibility, and caring for others

Risks & Challenges

Our two major challenges at the moment are capital and the COVID-19 pandemic. We will not pursue the brick & mortar pop-up until it is safe to do so. We will listen carefully to the advice of the CDC and other medical professionals on when a vaccine is available, and when it is safe to gather indoors again.

While it is a challenge, we also look at is as an opportunity to raise capital while we wait. That's why you can start taking online classes with us immediately, and why we will hold regular outdoor classes for as long as the weather allows.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute dollars, no worries! Reach out via email and let's chat. The very principle of a co-op is that everyone can be a part of it regardless of financial situation. We may need help with legal advice, networking, raising funds, creative design, and more.

If you or someone you know is interested in changing the yoga landscape with us, reach out! We're looking to grow the collective with committed, like-minded individuals ready for change. LGBTQ+ and teachers of color highly encouraged.

Spread the word! Follow us on Instagram. Talk about us with your community. Share our movement with your family and friends, and you become a part of the movement, too.

story:
The 35 Cinema: Where FILM comes BACK to the Cinema!

There's never been a better time to rediscover the magic of movies. And Las Vegas is home to the ultimate cinematic experience with The 35 Cinema....movies as the way they were meant to be seen.  Unlike our original location we will be FAMILY FRIENDLY!  this means you entire family can enjoy that classic feeling of going to the movies!

 

 

The 35 Cinema is the only multiplex theater of its kind in the world. What makes The 35 Cinema so special? It's a retro movie house that presents timeless classics and cult favorites the way they were originally made and shown...with genuine 35 millimeter film and projectors.  There are only a handful of theaters running 35mm film in the US.  But what make The 35 Cinema stand out about all the others is that it's the only 100% revival theater in the world running exclusively on 100% film!  We will not be playing anything after the year 2000.

Today's modern megaplexes utilize a totally digital format, essentially transforming their screens into over-sized televisions. Computers and electronic devices generate sound and imagery that are often called "hyper-realistic". While the goal of this technology is a perfect presentation, what's lacking, however is charm, warmth, and the intimacy of an old-time cinema.

The 35 Cinema restores the original format of movies, once thought to be lost forever. Let the sounds and flickering of 35mm projectors whisk you away on an unforgettable adventure. Classics like The Wizard of Oz, Singing In The Rain, Alien, 2001: A Space Odyssey, The Shining, Star Wars, Tron, A Nightmare On Elm Street...all of them were created using movie film, and nothing can replace the thrill of watching them that way.

Please note: The above video is not ours.  But it gives you a full idea of the workings of a 35mm projector.

At The 35 Cinema, our meticulously-restored systems are a part of the show. Projectors are located within view of the auditorium, not hidden out of sight.   Arrive early to watch our projectionist thread your movie through complex gears and pulleys, into a powerful lamp housing and onto massive take-up reels. Grab an ice-cold soft drink and a bag of the best popcorn in town, then settle in for vintage coming-attraction trailers before the landmark main feature

Photo from our original location

Along with being the coolest retro theater in the world, The 35 Cinema is the ultimate gathering spot for cine-philes of all ages. We offer an ever-expanding schedule of fan events, celebrity appearances, themed festivals and all-day marathons. Rare props, movie memorabilia, and dozens of autographed photos take you back to when you first saw your favorites on the silver screen.

Photo from our original location

One of the many events we'll be hosting will be our "Breakfast with the Toons" every Saturday and Sunday morning.  Where you'll be served a continental breakfast and get to watch two to three cartoon shorts before an animated feature!  The fun part about it is it'll be just like when you were a kid watching cartoons Saturday morning... You wont know what will be playing until it starts!

 

The 35 Cinema has so much to offer so... Don't miss this opportunity to be a part of the greatest cinematic experience of all time. The 35 Cinema - Movies The Way Were Meant To Be Seen.

Each month will be a different theme of movies!

 

 

Shane Bingham (General Manager) and John Lohmann (CEO) at our first location.

 

Here is a rough draft of the floor plan for our new location located in "The Commercial Center" in Las Vegas!

As you can see above our floor plan for our new location that includes a large concession stand, bar and three cinemas.  We also have areas of the theater that will be able to host VIP celebrity guests, original movie props and so much more.

Here are photos of our NEW LOCATION!

 

 

Media on "The 35 Cinema"

Here are just a few of the NEWS broadcasts "The 35 Cinema" was featured on at our first location!

 

 

 

 

What is money will be used for?

We already have some of the 35mm equipment in our possession, but we need more for additional auditoriums. We need help with funding to secure our new Las Vegas location, construction, additional concession equipment and more.

BUT IF WE RAISE MORE THEN OUR GOAL WE CAN MAKE THE THEATRE EVEN BETTER!

 

 

As a contributor you can take advantage of one of our many Rewards:

 

 

See you at the MOVIES!

 

Risks & Challenges

And what happens if The 35 Cinema doesn't meet its goal? If we don't succeed -- It would be a sad day for 35mm, Cinemas and Las Vegas as a whole.  We're relocating into a  space 6 times the size of our first location and we'll finally be family friendly (our first location was 21 and over due to the venue we were in.)

Our audience is growing and people are finding the magic of 35mm movies is still alive and we would love to keep it that way.  You have to try our popcorn as well... It has been called "The Best Popcorn In Town!"

If we succeed with your help, we'll immediately proceed with showing movies the way they were  meant to be seen... On film and on a silver screen!   We are The 35 Cinema!

story:
Project Summary

Contributors who fund Twin Cakes of Michigan are helping them add a refrigerated portable display case and related support items.

Twin Cakes started on a farm in Caledonia, Michigan when the twins were very young and now they are seeking to expand their offerings at the farmers market. 

This expansion need presented itself after a few years of offering pre-packaged selections as well as singles at the Calendonioa Farmers' Market.

This expansion allows them to support their customers' emerging needs.

We hope you will consider a donation to get this project fully funded.

What We Need & What You Get

Here is a breakdown of the reasoning for the expansion and adding of new equipment:

  • We are seeking a refrigerated case that will enable us to showcase more of the products we are creating.
  • We have some yummy perks that are all distributed at the Calendonia Farmers' Market. 
  • If we do not reach our goal on here, we will resort to other crowdsourcing activities like increasing our direct sales of cakes and other baked goods to entice folks to donate. 

The Impact

It is exciting to see the positive impact of Twin Cakes successfully running a small business in the food industry. Since the twins have been raised on a small Michigan farm, the importance of homemade has not been lost on them over the years. 

Most people who have ordered their cupcakes, which since day one has included gluten-free options as well as traditional, are very excited by their expansion.

The new case will enable them to add more purchasing options from their customers who are asking for more options when selecting their 4-packs or 6-packs of cupcakes.

People love choices and the twins are seeking to deliver what the customers are craving as they maximize their offerings via this new refrigerated unit.

Risks & Challenges

If Twin Cakes is not funded they run the risk of not advancing their business as they will have to return to the old method, which does not allow for customization of boxed items. It also runs the risk of halting their growth at a time when folks are just starting to venture out after a long 15 months of COVID-19 restrictions. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot donate, we invite you to visit Twin Cakes at the Caledonia Farmers' Market this summer. Or if that is too far, please join our mailing list to be kept in the loop as you can celebrate our joy in growing a business from scatch, which is just like the cakes we make.

- Ella and Lola of Twin Cakes

story:
Gift of Happiness Foundation is totally dedicated to helping poor children and families in Thailand.

The idea of starting this charity was born in 1995 by British and Swedish born circus performers, Mr, Mrs Eddie & Charlotte Haworth when they were running their UK circus skill training workshops for disadvantaged kids in Liverpool, England.

In the year 2000, Eddie was invited to perform at a charity event held at the British Embassy in Bangkok, Thailand.  Following that performance and a few more for the slum kids in Bangkok, it was quickly decided to bring more gifts of laughter and educational entertainment to orphans and other children in Thailand.

Now supported by a team of dedicated volunteers, Gift of Happiness Foundation is not tied to supporting just a few children at only one location. Therefore, this unique charity has the freedom to provide joy to thousands of children in urban and remote locations throughout the country.

Absolute dedication from everyone at this small but effective charity.

The Founder/Director, administrators, drivers and all other volunteers DO NOT get paid one cent at Gift of Happiness Foundation. We are all early retired or employed elsewhere but have enough time to volunteer our services to help some of the neediest people in this country every month of every year. 

What we actually do.

The Foundation regularly gives simple interactive and educational comedy shows to those whose lives quite often contain little joy. We also give away tons of essential goods during our monthly aid giving projects. All this is delivered where it's needed most in hired trucks and the Directors own vehicle. 

Who we help.

Orphans, vulnerable street children, Bangkok slum dwellers, families living on garbage dumps, AIDS centres and facilities housing physically or mentally challenged children. We regularly serve medical centres, crisis centres for abused women, communities of migrant worker families and people displaced by civil war who live in refugee camps.

What we actually give.

The charity gives children and their family’s basic necessities like clothing, bedding, medical supplies, educational equipment, toys, agricultural tools and tons more useful goods. The children always get to see a top class professional comedy show to leave them with a fantastic memory that no-one can ever steel from them!

What we need to keep doing this important job.

Simple...We need our own delivery truck to transport all the goods to 1,000 children in need every month. This will cost $30,000.00 to buy and the charity pays maintenance costs. 

If we do not reach our entire goal, we will use any money raised to buy a used truck or put towards the costs of hiring enough transport to get the goods delivered for as many months as possible. 

Why we need it now.

Until recently we have been fortunate enough to have some support from a wealthy individual who provided us with one or two of his pick-up trucks to transport the essential goods to the people who really need them. Now we have sadly lost our one and only wealthy benefactor and this has left us with a massive logistical headache. 

Your contribution will help us continue bringing tons of essential goods to 1,000 children every month!

We are very successful at acquiring enough goods  in Bangkok to fill two or three truckloads every month.  Most of the goods come from International Schoolchildren, Hotels, Women's Groups and Loyal Society members. Some are sent from outside Thailand by individuals from all parts of the world.

All the goods are sorted and packed by a few volunteers who make everything ready for the monthly seven hour drive up to the Northern Thai/Burma borders or to be given locally in the slums of Bangkok. 

A lot of these deliveries happen during our aid and show giving project tours located in the jungles and mountains of Northern Thailand, so we are always in need of sturdy 4x4 vehicles capable of reaching the most remote villages communities.
story_txt:
Gift of Happiness Foundation is totally dedicated to helping poor children and families in
Thailand.



The idea of starting this charity was born in 1995 by British and Swedish born circus performers, Mr, Mrs Eddie & Charlotte Haworth when they were running their UK circus skill training workshops for disadvantaged kids in Liverpool, England.
In the year 2000, Eddie was invited to perform at a charity event held at the British Embassy in Bangkok, Thailand.  Following that performance and a few more for the slum kids in Bangkok, it was quickly decided to bring more gifts of laughter and educational entertainment to orphans and other children in Thailand.
Now supported by a team of dedicated volunteers, Gift of
Happiness Foundation is not tied to supporting just a few children at only one
location. Therefore, this unique charity has the freedom to provide joy to
thousands of children in urban and remote locations throughout the country.
Absolute dedication from everyone at this small but effective charity.
The Founder/Director, administrators, drivers and all other volunteers DO NOT get paid one cent at Gift of Happiness Foundation. We are all early retired or employed elsewhere but have enough time to volunteer our services to help some of the neediest people in this country every month of every year. 
What we actually do.
The Foundation regularly gives simple interactive and
educational comedy shows to those whose lives quite often contain little joy.
We also give away tons of essential goods during our monthly aid giving projects. All this is delivered where it's needed most in hired trucks and the Directors own vehicle. 
Who we help.
Orphans, vulnerable street children, Bangkok slum
dwellers, families living on garbage dumps, AIDS centres and facilities housing
physically or mentally challenged children. We regularly serve medical centres,
crisis centres for abused women, communities of migrant worker families and
people displaced by civil war who live in refugee camps.
What we actually
give.
The charity gives children and their family’s basic
necessities like clothing, bedding, medical supplies, educational equipment, toys,
agricultural tools and tons more useful goods. The children always get to see a
top class professional comedy show to leave them with a fantastic memory that
no-one can ever steel from them!

What we need to keep doing this important job.
Simple...We need our own delivery truck to transport all the goods to 1,000 children in need every month. This will cost $30,000.00 to buy and the charity pays maintenance costs. 
If we do not reach our entire goal, we will use any money raised to buy a used truck or put towards the costs of hiring enough transport to get the goods delivered for as many months as possible. 
Why we need it now.
Until recently we have been fortunate enough to have some support from a wealthy individual who provided us with one or two of his pick-up trucks to transport the essential goods to the people who really need them. Now we have sadly lost our one and only wealthy benefactor and this has left us with a massive logistical headache. 
Your contribution will help us continue bringing tons of essential goods to 1,000 children every month!
We are very successful at acquiring enough goods  in Bangkok to fill two or three truckloads every month.  Most of the goods come from International Schoolchildren, Hotels, Women's Groups and Loyal Society members. Some are sent from outside Thailand by individuals from all parts of the world.
All the goods are sorted and packed by a few volunteers who make everything ready for the monthly seven hour drive up to the Northern Thai/Burma borders or to be given locally in the slums of Bangkok. 
A lot of these deliveries happen during our aid and show giving project tours located in the jungles and mountains of Northern Thailand, so we are always in need of sturdy 4x4 vehicles capable of reaching the most remote villages communities.

story:
His Holiness Bhakti Tirtha Swami was a spiritual mentor and exemplar of spiritual warriorship to thousands of us, all over the world. We are gathering in Gita Nagari in Port Royal, Pennsylvania, June 25-29, 2015, to commemorate the 10th anniversary of his passing.

We are hoping that you will join us to discuss and experience his legacy. What does it mean to have had such an incredible mentor? How do we act on and share that blessing? Not only do we want you to attend, and your loved ones if they can, we would like you to help us with the cost of the memorial celebration. 

We humbly ask that disciples of H.H. Bhakti Tirtha Swami that are not attending kindly please donate a minimum of $150.00 as an offering to Maharaja as a heartfelt service to help cover the festival costs whether you plan on attending or not. Thank you. Funds raised through this channel will go toward the cost of putting on the festival - feast ingredients/bhoga, tents, cleaning supplies, renting the Gita Nagari grounds and facilities for each of the days, etc.   

Make a donation, large or small, to offset the weight often and regularly carried by the same devout families. Make a donation because you love the prasadam. 

Śrīla Rūpa Gosvāmī explains and Srila Prabhupada shares in the Nectar of Devotion the six loving exhanges between devotees.  

"Offering gifts in charity, accepting charitable gifts, revealing one's mind in confidence, inquiring confidentially, accepting prasāda and offering prasāda are the six symptoms of love shared by one devotee and another" (http://vaniquotes.org/wiki/Six_loving_exchanges).

This is what we are getting together in Gita Nagari to do, in honor of Bhakti Tirtha Swami whom we admire and adore for his enthusiasm and exemplary loving service to Radha and Krsna and their devotees. On behalf of all the devotees involved, Tamal Krishna, Madhvacarya, Kartmisha and countless others, you are invited. Come talk about challenges and successes in your life and what his example means to you. Dance, laugh and eat and reveal your heart with us. First, give in charity.

Attributions: Cover photo is from the BTSwami.com archive. Video "Bhakti Tirtha Swami - Tribute to a Spiritual Warrior" was created by devotees in 2005 and is available on Adideva's YouTube Channel.


***Please note that this website is for donations ONLY and NOT for festival registration. Contributions of any amount from disciples and well-wishers are greatly appreciated. To register for the festival, please visit the registration site here: http://btswami2015.eventbee.com/event?eid=147429632

story:
Background and short summary 

When I came to Ecuador for the first time, about a year ago, I got surprised by food and agriculture there. I thought there would be much more variety in food served, given the fact that Ecuador has the highest natural biodiversity in the world.. But no, mostly rice, chicken and quite tasteless salad for lunch there. While there is so much variety of food possible to be grown with the good climate and fertile soil Ecuador has!

We see a potential for marketing a larger variety of vegetables, grains, fruits, milk products like cheese and processed products like pesto, tomato sauce and tapenades.  
There is  a demand for more diverse and nutritional food but yet it isn't produced sufficient locally. So, where to start? 
Locally of course. With my experience in organic horticulture, we will focus on growing, processing and marketing a wide variety of crops - as much variety as possible, meanwhile producing in efficient and sustainable ways.
Gabriela, my girlfriend and team-member, nice to meet you, will focus on facilitating the farm for visitors and volunteers to have an experience on the land and get involved in permaculture and other ecological ways of providing food. 
For our one-year old daughter it would be very beneficial to spend time outside and get in touch with the growth of food, living animals and nature. We want to give others that oppurtunity as well, opening up our farm for visitors and volunteers. 
In short, our project's idea started with a personal wish and then we discovered a lot of people have the same wishes, in Ecuador too. Eating good food, breathing the fresh air and coming to your senses in nature or on a farm is what we all appreciate. 

What We Need & What You Get

The money raised by crowdfunding will be spent on creating a small-scale farm nearby Quito. What we need to have to make this farm reality, is:
- Fertile land, not much further as an hour from Quito, which we focus on for selling our products.  On this land, we will create various ecosystems, like an agro-forestry part and a pond with a swamp, to create the ideal growing conditions for all species. The creation of ecosystems takes time but once established will be very beneficial for our farm and surroundings.   
- A greenhouse which will contain a plant nursery - which we can build ourselves. We have already build several and they perform well. 
- Facilities to store and process our harvest - A low-cost farm building, simple, from materials in the area, like wood and clay. 
- Several tools, like hoes and shovels. A tractor is a dream for later.
- A small trailer to transport our produce to several markets and stores in Quito.
What you will get depends on your wishes. If you happen to be in Ecuador, we would like to support your contribution by providing food, lodging and a place for volunteering on our project. If you do not happen to be in Ecuador, like the majority, we send hand-made fabric bags with our logo on it, filled with our folders, delicious organic Ecuadorian products, like chocolate, coffee and quinoa to your doorstep.. Or you can pick it up on Stadsboerderij Ceatshage in Culemborg or De Hoge Born in Wageningen, Netherlands.  

The Impact

For us as a family the Impact will be very great. We will live on our farm and start a new life together. We are looking forward to that moment!

For the community around us this project will be beneficial too. By sharing seeds and knowledge about agriculture, by opening up a market for fresh local products from farms around us and by opening up the farm to visitors and volunteers which will benefit the local stores and local tourist branche. 

The contributor will trigger a sustainable green revolution in Ecuador, based on local produce and open-source seed and knowledge sharing, making the area more 'edible', educative and attractive for visitors and volunteers. These people will stimulate local economy and hopefully spread seeds and knowledge further. 

My succesful track record in creating projects started on his 4-year study in Biodynamic Agriculture, in the Netherlands. With some classmates I grew a purple, sprouting variety of broccoli. In those days, this vegetable was not well-known on organic markets in the Netherlands. The little bundles of purple sprouts were welcomed with much enthusiasm by the customers. They could have grown much more. For the marketmen, this new product was a welcome complement to their existing assortiment. It attracted more attention to their stand. 
We hope for the same enthusiasm when we introduce vegetables like snappy asian and curly salads,  tiger and zebra tomatoes, french long radish, rainbow chards, Chioggia red beets, shallots, Thai and purple basilic and indigeneous types of corn, potatoes, quinoa, amaranth and beans. 
Gabriela's succesful track record in projects and interest in nature and food started with researching on the behaviour of monkeys in the Amazone, to researching nutritional aspects of a highland Andean community, volunteering in permacultural projects and later with the birth of our daughter. She is a fantastic mother. 

Risks & Challenges

A risk will be that we run out of money before we sell our first salads. To prevent that, we will make a good business-plan. With my former education, I learned how to make one for farm-scale. We will only make the most necessary investments first and when 'things start rolling' invest more to reach more people. 

Another risk will be that we can not get access to a small piece of good land. This seems rather unlikely, because there is a lot of land available in Ecuador. Though, if we don't find our own piece of land, we will start on an existing farm and do the same. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute for the perks, a single dollar or euro would be really appreciated to! On any donation under 30,- we will send you a newsletter about our progress.

Sharing this project with others is as valuable as contributing money to us. This way, we get in touch with more people to cooperate with. 

There are Indiegogo share tools to spread the word.

story:
My husband and I...

have had the desire for 11+ years to bring an indoor skate park to our town. We feel that God has given us this vision and we are His people setting out to accomplish His plan. We have a huge heart for the youth. We know skating is a passion for so many of them, but we want to offer them more. Our heart is to guide students into finding their passions in life, offer them a safe place to discover what those passions are, and give them the stepping stones to follow them. 

NOT JUST A SKATE PARK...

The skate park is just the beginning.  We want students to find their place in our community and in their future.    We want to guide them in finding, and acting out their visions and passions.  We plan on helping in the entry process of college, technical school, or the work field. We look forward to implementing classes, such as cooking and  financial, classes to prepare them for life after high school.  We will be available to assist with school work in the form of tutorials.  We'd like to be equipped with the technology students need to complete their school work and projects.  
Our desire is to have students play a big of a role in the park, as we run it.  We envision them leading skate lessons and day camps for younger kids.   Students will have incentives for free skate, in exchange for volunteer hours in the community.  They will also have free skate privileges for good or improved grades. We plan on having students display their art work in our display windows to tie into our amazing murals seen throughout our town. These kids have different gifts, and art is one of them.  We want to show them off.  
Some students are currently volunteering with fund raisers. They have taken this very seriously.  They are stepping up and speaking to business owners and managers, while we sit back and watch them go. They are already talking about how they will be active in taking care of the facility. These kids have pride and dedication to this endeavor, we know the park will be well taken care of by them. They are on fire with ideas on how to make this a success, and we, no doubt, believe in their ideas!
Neither my husband nor myself are, or ever were, skaters.  We do, however recognize that these students in our community need someone to back them up. We are here to let them know, we will not give up on this journey.  We WILL see this out to it's completion!

Where you come in...

Our desire is that anyone who wants to skate, can skate.  An entry fee should not keep kids away.  The more funding we can get, the less the students will have to pay.  This is why we want to have a building paid off, so other monies can be used to pay for kids to skate.  We live in a low income community, and we want to reach ALL the kids, not just those who can afford it. This is a huge undertaking, bigger than ourselves.  Without contributors like you, this can not be a success.  
We don't want to negate contributors who invest in us. We have set up perks, as a small way to say thank you. Please see our perks on the sidebar.

Risks & Challenges

We know we are taking huge risks.  The reputation of city skate parks are not always pretty.  Vandalism, loitering, fighting, alcohol and drug use seem to be reoccurring issues for many parks.  This is why it's important that the skaters are involved in the creativity of the park.  This is also why it's important that we have an indoor facility; in order to build a supportive, trusting community with the youth, and provide opportunities an outdoor park may not provide.  We will encourage them to lead fund raising efforts, skate lessons, and creating other skating related activities such as skate competitions. If they have ownership, these risks will be replaced with pride and ownership in the facility. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Not everyone is able to contribute financially, but there are other ways you can contribute. Check out our website at wingsofeaglesskatepark.com for more ways to contribute.   Help us get the word out.  Tell others, who have a heart for skaters, or just a big heart for kids.  Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools. and above all PRAY for us!!
